repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This allows things to work like:

    # in pxd file
    from libc.math cimport sin

    # in py file
    if not cython.compiled:
        from math import sin  # previously failed with cython compile
           # error because it was assigning to a cdef name

This seems worthwhile because it makes it easier to generate code
that re-assigns cdef names and so works in both modes.

For the sake of simplicitity it only handles very simple cases
and doesn't attempt a full exercise in constant folding at this
stage (hence `if not cython.compiled and True` isn't handled).
This seems like a sensible compromise.

comment_data.body: This comment is a bit outdated now.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -630,6 +630,10 @@ class InterpretCompilerDirectives(CythonTransform):
     - Command-line arguments overriding these
     - @cython.directivename decorators
     - with cython.directivename: statements
+    - removes unreachable blocks from if-statements like

comment_data.body:
If these were in functions, you could apply a tree assertion decorator to make sure that the if-statements are really getting discarded and only the expected conditional blocks are left in.

Also, this test isn't really about "pure if-clauses". I suggest naming it `cython_compiled_folding.py`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,27 @@
+# mode: compile
+
+# libc sin, cos and sqrt cimported in the pxd file
+
+import cython
+
+if not cython.compiled:
+    from math import sin
+
+if cython.compiled:

comment_data.body: A test for the plain `NameNode` case seems to be missing. All tests use `cython.compiled`, none uses something like `from cython import compiled` (and I'm not even sure that that is tested anywhere else yet…).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -846,6 +850,16 @@ def visit_NameNode(self, node):
             directive = self.directive_names.get(node.name)
             if directive is not None:
                 node.cython_attribute = directive
+        if node.as_cython_attribute() == "compiled":

comment_data.body: I've done this. I'm not sure the tree decorator assertion is hugely meaningful - I think the blocks were always optimized out at some point. However it doesn't hurt to have it there
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,27 @@

+# libc sin, cos and sqrt cimported in the pxd file
+
+import cython
+
+if not cython.compiled:
+    from math import sin
+
+if cython.compiled:

commit.message:
Dropped unused code-paths associated with if cython.compiled early

This allows things to work like:
    # in pxd file
    from libc.math cimport sin

    # in py file
    if not cython.compiled:
        from math import sin  # previously failed with cython compile
           # error because it was assigning to a cdef name

This seems worthwhile because it makes it easier to generate code
that re-assigns cdef names and so works in both modes.

For the sake of simplicitity it only handles very simple cases
and doesn't attempt a full exercise in constant folding at this
stage (hence `if not cython.compiled and True` isn't handled).
This seems like a sensible compromise.
Replaced with `BoolNode` and let `ConstantFolding` do the work instead

Removed "compiled" from transform builtin methods

Since it's evaluated earlier
Updated comments, moved tests, added tests

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Drop unused code-paths associated with "if cython.compiled" early
